content.title: Reverse-Complement Consistency for DNA Language Models
content.abstract:
A fundamental property of DNA is that the \textbf{reverse complement (RC)} of a sequence often carries identical biological meaning. 
However, state-of-the-art DNA language models frequently fail to capture this symmetry, producing inconsistent predictions for a sequence and its RC counterpart, which undermines their reliability. 
In this work, we introduce Reverse-Complement Consistency Regularization (RCCR), a simple and model-agnostic fine-tuning objective that directly penalizes the divergence between a model's prediction on a sequence and the aligned prediction on its reverse complement. 
We evaluate RCCR across three diverse backbones (Nucleotide Transformer, HyenaDNA, DNABERT-2) on a wide range of genomic tasks, including sequence classification, scalar regression, and profile prediction. 
Our experiments show that RCCR substantially improves RC-robustness by dramatically reducing prediction flips and errors, all while maintaining or improving task accuracy compared to baselines like RC data augmentation and test-time averaging. 
By integrating a key biological prior directly into the learning process, RCCR produces a single, intrinsically robust, and computationally efficient model fine-tuning recipe for diverse biology tasks.
content.tldr: Propose a method of finetuning DNA LMs for RC equivariant tasks.
keywords: DNA Language Model; Reverse-Complement; Foundation Model
content.primary_area: applications to physical sciences (physics, chemistry, biology, etc.)

summary.value: This paper incorporates the reverse-complement (RC) concept in DNA into training DNA foundation models. With this biologically plausible insight, they show it theoretically improve tasks that require such symmetry. Empirical evaluation with three foundation models and three benchmark evaluations better validate this approach. This work is pretty self-contained and complete to me.

strengths.value:
1. The paper is clearly written and the overall presentation is very good. (No correction needed)

2. The experiment design is well-thought-out and covers various models and tasks that are important in this field.

3. The design of the non-RC task is also a good choice.

weaknesses.value:
**Significance of the results.**

The statistical differences across methods in Table 1 appear minimal. Can the authors provide the standard deviation for these results to show their statistical significance?

**How is RC implemented in NT-v2?**

How is the Reverse-Complement (RC) symmetry being implemented in these models? Additionally, what procedure do the authors use if the sequence length is not a multiple of 6 for NT-v2 (e.g., how are sequences padded or truncated)?

questions.value:
**Combining RCCR with RC-Aug / TTA**

While the results are convincing enough to me, I wonder if using RCCR along with RC-Aug would give synergic effect with combining with RC-Aug or TTA?

summary.value: The authors proposed an approach to regularize the loss function of DNA LMs during fine-tuning for incorporating RC equivariance. I found the approach to be easy-to-use and technically sound. Though I have some reservations about the empirical evidence because: 1. The backbone DNA LMs picked by the authors have questionable transfer learning capability over naive baselines; 2. There are no evaluations on zero-shot variant effect prediction. I therefore consider this work to be a borderline case.

strengths.value:
1. The authors proposed an easy-to-use strategy for building in RC equivariance into arbitrary DNA LMs. 
2. The authors selected a relatively broad set of evaluation tasks, and there are sufficient details about the experimental setups.
3. The proposed method is technically sound with some basic theoretical justifications.

weaknesses.value:
1. My main concern is that the backbone DNA LMs picked by the authors are the underperforming ones, whose transfer learning benefit over baseline (no pretraining) is questionable according to a few recent studies (https://genomebiology.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13059-025-03674-8, https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.12.18.628606v2). It might be more convincing to demonstrate the approach using Evo 2 (https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2025.02.18.638918v1), a newer model that showed non-trivial improvements over baselines on certain tasks. 

2. RC-aug and TTA can actually be used together and were used by models such as GPN. It would be good to add these two combined as an additional baseline.

3. The authors only evaluated transfer learning tasks. Zero-shot variant effect prediction is also an important task and arguably more reliable for benchmarking purposes, as being emphasized in Evo 2, GPN, and NT papers. It would be good to evaluate on some of those benchmarks too.

4. The regularization term is task-dependent in the current approach, which limits its use for tasks without the need for fine-tuning or transfer learning. It would have been better to extend it for pretraining as well.

questions.value: It might be nice to have a diagram to show the workflow of the proposed approach.

summary.value: This manuscript tackles the problem of reverse-complement (RC) inconsistency in DNA foundation models, where a model gives different outputs for a sequence and its RC version despite a symmetric biological label. The authors introduce Reverse-Complement Consistency Regularization (RCCR), a straightforward fine-tuning objective that penalizes this predictive divergence. The proposed method is evaluated across three different model backbones (NT-v2, HyenaDNA, DNABERT-2) on a variety of genomic tasks. The results show that RCCR makes models significantly more robust to RC transformations (measured by new SFR and RC-Corr metrics) without hurting, and sometimes helping, task performance.

strengths.value:
### Method Generality

The proposed method, RCCR, is flexible and model-agnostic: As a drop-in regularization term, it can be applied to pretrained foundation models without requiring architectural changes. This is a practical advantage over methods that build equivariance into the model's structure.   

### Empirical Evaluation

The authors conducted throughout experiments to validate the performance of their proposed method.

weaknesses.value:
### Limited Motivation

The paper's motivation rests on the principle that many genomic tasks are RC-symmetric. However, biological processes like transcription are directional, and genes can be encoded on either the plus or minus strand. Clarifying why the RC-symmetry assumption is appropriate for the specific tasks chosen (e.g., histone modification, gene expression) would strengthen the biological grounding of the work. 

## RC-Invariance Assumption for Splice Site Prediction

The manuscript categorizes splice site detection as a "fundamentally RC-invariant" task. This claim requires justification, as canonical splice sites (e.g., GT-AG dinucleotides) are strand-specific motifs. Their reverse complements are not functional splice sites. The authors should provide a justification for applying an RC-invariance prior to this task. The discrepancy between the biological reality of the task and the model's inductive bias needs to be addressed.

summary.value: This work implements Reverse Complement Consistency Regularization (RCCR), a post-hoc method to add some form of reverse complement equivariance to existing DNA LMs regardless of architecture by adding in a loss term that enforces that embeddings of the fwd and rev sequence of DNA should be the same. This work proposes some theory about RCCR and evaluates the effects of fine-tuning 3 existing DNA LMs with this RCCR objective.

strengths.value: This paper is well written, and goes into a fair bit of detail and theory about how exactly this method is implemented and some theoretical implications about RCCR.

weaknesses.value:
This work on initial reads seems like a post-hoc way of applying the same (or a very similar) for of RC-equivariance that Caducues used to other models, severely limiting the novelty of this work. I understand that the architectures studied in this work are different than Caducues, this work seems to be covering a substantially similar space and it's not clear to me on first read what exactly the novelty here is. Caducues already had experiment showing the benefits of RC-equivariance, which are repeated here (albeit on a more comprehensive set of tasks), so I believe the idea that RC-equivarance being useful is not novel. Additionally this method (which I'll paraphrase as adding a symmetric KL term to the loss) seems to have the same effect as the RC-equivariance that Caduceus enforced through it's design. 

I believe this work covers many of the same ideas as Cadcueus, just applying post-hoc to different models and therefore do not see much novelty in this work. 

If the authors can show significant gains or tangible differences of their post-hoc approach compared to Caduceus, I'm willing to re-evaluate my initial assessment, but at the moment I don't see any tangible gains or much novelty in this approach.

questions.value: 1. How different is this work from the RC-equivariance that caduceus enforced? Specifically, say I train a Non-RC-equivariant version of Cadcueus (the -PH version iirc) and apply this post-hoc method, how does that compare to cadcueus trained to be RC-equivariant from the beginning (the -PS version)?
